title: Wild Zora Potential Hire Survey
introduction: This survey helps us understand how your personal values align with our company culture. Please answer each question honestly. There are no right or wrong answers.

categories.name: Optimism
categories.description: How you approach challenges and setbacks

categories.name: Productivity & Continuous Improvement
categories.description: Your work habits and improvement approaches

categories.name: Value Orientation
categories.description: Your focus on ROI and business value

categories.name: Collaboration
categories.description: Your teamwork, communication, and interpersonal skills

questions.text: When you come across a new and complicated challenge, which approach feels most natural?

options.text: Start immediately and learn as you go.
Break it into smaller steps and tackle them one by one.
Consider the worst-case scenario to be prepared for all outcomes.
Check if someone else has dealt with a similar problem before.

questions.text: If things don't go according to plan, how do you usually respond in the moment?

options.text: Spend time figuring out who or what caused the issue.
Accept it as a sign that more thorough planning was needed.
Take a step back and question whether the goal is still worth pursuing.
Remind myself that setbacks happen and look for a workaround.

questions.text: Thinking back to a recent personal or professional disappointment, which best describes your reaction?

options.text: I considered giving up altogether before reassessing.
I took a break from the situation to regroup later.
I found a lesson in it and moved forward.
I vented to others but eventually moved on.

questions.text: When beginning a new project, how would you describe your initial mindset?

options.text: Neutral; I wait to see the first results before feeling strongly.
Mostly optimistic; I believe there's a good chance of success.
Apprehensive; I assume obstacles will arise right away.
Cautious; I foresee possible problems but remain hopeful.

questions.text: When you hear about a major setback happening in your organization or team, what's your first thought?

options.text: This could be a bigger problem than we realize.
I wonder who or what is to blame.
Sometimes these things happen and we just have to deal with it.
There must be a way to turn this around.

questions.text: Reflecting on a time something went wrong, what usually keeps you motivated in the aftermath?

options.text: Hope that the situation might resolve itself.
My sense of obligation to finish what I start.
The idea that I can learn from it and do better next time.
Knowing that others have rebounded from worse situations.

questions.text: When you encounter repeated challenges, which statement best matches your perspective?

options.text: They're usually the fault of poor preparation.
They're reasons to rethink the original plan.
They're a sign that I might need external help or resources.
They're opportunities to test and build resilience.

questions.text: How do you typically structure your day to stay on top of tasks?

options.text: I rely on memory and handle things on the fly.
I use external reminders or colleagues to keep me on track.
I use a prioritized list or schedule and work through it methodically.
I address tasks as they come, focusing on what feels most urgent.

questions.text: After completing a big project, how do you usually review your performance?

options.text: I reflect only if something went wrong.
I assess what went well and note what could be improved next time.
I tend to move on quickly without much formal reflection.
I mainly check if I met deadlines and budget requirements.

questions.text: When you notice an inefficiency in a process, which action are you most likely to take?

options.text: Adapt my own workflow but keep it to myself.
Work around it unless it becomes a bigger problem.
Mention it casually to a teammate or manager and see if they agree.
Document it, propose improvements, and test a new solution.

questions.text: How do you measure your own productivity on a day-to-day basis?

options.text: By the number of tasks I check off.
By feedback from colleagues or clients.
By how well I accomplish my most important goals.
I don't measure; I just keep working until everything is done.

questions.text: Think of a habit or skill you wanted to improve over the past year. How did you approach it?

options.text: I attended workshops or found external resources for guidance.
I didn't have a structured plan; I just hoped to get better over time.
I improved gradually through trial and error.
I set clear milestones and tracked my progress consistently.

questions.text: When an unexpected task appears, how do you integrate it into your schedule?

options.text: I postpone other tasks to make immediate room for it.
I re-evaluate priorities and adjust deadlines if needed.
I add it in if it fits without significantly changing my routine.
I often juggle tasks spontaneously and see what gets done first.

questions.text: Looking at your work or personal routines, how do you decide what to improve next?

options.text: I look for quick fixes with noticeable immediate gains.
I prioritize based on what others expect or request.
I focus on what will have the greatest overall impact.
I tend to leave things as they are unless there's a direct complaint.

questions.text: When selecting projects or opportunities, which factor do you find most persuasive?

options.text: The extent of resources required (time, money, people).
The chance to work on something innovative or interesting.
The immediate financial return, even if it's small.
The potential for lasting value or impact, even if delayed.

questions.text: In situations where revenues or savings are unpredictable, which response best describes you?

options.text: I focus on alternative ways to create stability or backup income.
I maintain flexibility and adjust budgets or plans as needed.
I take conservative measures and avoid risk.
I proceed with the original plan and adapt only if forced to.

questions.text: When faced with a difficult conversation at work (e.g., delivering bad news), how do you usually handle it?

options.text: Deliver the message quickly and move on.
Focus on preserving harmony, even if it means skirting details.
Speak directly but try to maintain a constructive tone.
Discuss it only if I'm directly asked; otherwise, I avoid conflict.

questions.text: How do you typically receive constructive criticism from others?

options.text: I take a note of it, but I might not change my approach right away.
I usually challenge it to see if the criticism is truly valid.
I might feel a bit defensive but try to remain polite.
I consider their perspective and see if it can help me improve.

questions.text: When a colleague disagrees with your plan, what's your most likely reaction?

options.text: Defend my plan until I'm convinced otherwise.
Ask for details to understand the reasons behind their concerns.
Encourage them to explain but ultimately trust my own judgment.
Try to compromise quickly so we can move forward.

questions.text: During teamwork, how do you prefer to handle differing opinions?

options.text: Seek a neutral mediator or manager to decide.
Let the majority decide to keep things moving.
Stick to my view unless there's a clear reason to change.
Have an open discussion to weigh all sides.

questions.text: When giving feedback, which statement best reflects your style?

options.text: I soften my words so I don't demotivate the other person.
I try to be direct yet considerate, focusing on the situation not the person.
I provide direct feedback only if it's requested.
I prefer not to give feedback in group settings, only 1-to-1.

questions.text: If a teammate is struggling with their tasks, how do you react?

options.text: Offer moral support but let them figure it out.
Avoid getting involved so I can focus on my own duties.
Offer help or guidance if I have the capacity.
Suggest they speak to someone more qualified.

questions.text: You've had a personal conflict with a teammate. Which response best describes how you handle it?

options.text: I inform a manager or third party to help resolve it.
I schedule a private talk and try to find a mutual understanding.
I keep the relationship strictly professional and limit personal interaction.
I do my best to ignore it, hoping it fades over time.

questions.text: When you think about personal or professional growth, what motivates you to keep going?

options.text: I'm motivated by proving myself to others.
I'm driven by achieving bigger goals or milestones.
I'm mostly motivated by external rewards (e.g., financial, recognition).
I'm energized by learning new skills or knowledge.

questions.text: How do you typically celebrate your wins—big or small?

options.text: I keep the celebration internal; I'm not big on public recognition.
I move on quickly to the next thing without much pause.
I pause to reflect and share my gratitude with those who helped.
I reward myself with something I enjoy.

questions.text: When working with others, what do you value most in your teammates?

options.text: Their ability to follow through on commitments.
Their willingness to collaborate and share ideas.
Their expertise and skill level in their role.
Their efficiency and ability to work independently.

questions.text: In a group setting, how do you typically contribute to discussions?

options.text: I listen carefully and speak up when I have something valuable to add.
I prefer to observe and process information before commenting.
I actively participate and share my thoughts and ideas.
I tend to lead the conversation and keep it moving forward.

questions.text: When receiving recognition for team accomplishments, how do you typically respond?

options.text: I acknowledge my contribution but emphasize the team effort.
I highlight the specific contributions of team members.
I accept the recognition graciously but briefly.
I feel uncomfortable with praise and try to redirect attention.

questions.text: What motivates you to keep going when you face challenges?

options.text: I'm motivated by proving myself to others.
I'm driven by achieving bigger goals or milestones.
I'm mostly motivated by external rewards (e.g., financial, recognition).
I'm energized by learning new skills or knowledge.

questions.text: How do you typically approach new opportunities?

options.text: I carefully weigh the pros and cons before deciding.
I jump in quickly to avoid missing out.
I consider how it aligns with my long-term goals.
I seek advice from others before making a decision.

interpretation.high: You have a strong optimistic outlook and resilience when facing challenges.
interpretation.medium: You have a balanced approach to challenges, with moderate optimism.
interpretation.low: You tend to be more cautious and realistic when approaching challenges.

interpretation.high: You have strong productivity habits and a proactive approach to improvement.
interpretation.medium: You have a balanced approach to productivity and improvement.
interpretation.low: You may benefit from developing more structured productivity habits.

interpretation.high: You have a strong focus on ROI and business value in your decision-making.
interpretation.medium: You balance business value with other considerations in your decisions.
interpretation.low: You may prioritize factors other than direct business value in your decisions.

interpretation.high: You have strong collaborative skills and work well with others.
interpretation.medium: You have a balanced approach to teamwork and collaboration.
interpretation.low: You may prefer independent work over collaborative environments.

interpretation.high: You show strong self-awareness and personal motivation.
interpretation.medium: You have a balanced level of self-awareness and motivation.
interpretation.low: You may benefit from reflecting more on your personal motivations.
